excerpt: 16th-century Gothic palace covered in symbolic seashell motifs, now an exhibition space & library.
detail_description: Casa de las Conchas, also known as the House of Shells, is a 16th-century Gothic palace in Salamanca. Its facade is adorned with over 300 intricately carved seashells, symbolizing the original owner's affiliation with the Order of Santiago de Compostela. This historic building has served various purposes throughout its existence, including as a dwelling, university edifice, and even a correctional facility.
name: Casa de las Conchas
address: C. de la Compañía, 2, 37002 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: Working university founded in 13th century, with an ornate carved entrance & 16th-century classroom.
detail_description: The University of Salamanca, established in the 13th century, boasts an intricate carved entrance and a 16th-century classroom. The institution has a rich history, with students initially studying at the Cathedral of Salamanca due to lack of physical space. Over time, the university's construction was completed in the 15th century. Despite its historical significance, recent controversies have emerged involving retracted scientific papers authored by Juan Manuel Corchado, the university's rector.
name: University of Salamanca

excerpt: Art nouveau & art deco museum in a mansion with colorful glass, jewelry & a collection of dolls.
detail_description: Museo Art Nouveau y Art Déco - Casa Lis is a museum housed in a stunning art nouveau mansion, featuring colorful glass, jewelry, and an extensive collection of dolls. The museum showcases the decorative arts from the 19th century, emphasizing quality craftsmanship and exquisite finishes. Visitors can immerse themselves in the beauty of art nouveau and art deco while exploring this impressive collection within the mansion's elegant surroundings.
name: Museo Art Nouveau y Art Déco - Casa Lis

detail_description: Salamanca's Plaza Mayor is a grand and imposing public square that has been central to city life since its construction between 1729 and 1755. The plaza features Baroque-style architecture, with a continuous four-storey building surrounding it, as well as the grand City Hall (Ayuntamiento). Originally intended for bullfights and local festivals, the square is now an attractive spot for al fresco dining and is most beautiful when illuminated in the evening.
name: Plaza Mayor

detail_description: The Convento de San Esteban, a Dominican monastery located near the Puente Nuevo, boasts a splendid church with lavish Plateresque decoration. Built between 1524 and 1610, the church features a gilded high altar by Jose de Churriguera and impressive side altars. This prime example of plateresque style architecture showcases Baroque and Renaissance elements. The facade is particularly remarkable with intricate carvings depicting the Martyrdom of Saint Stephen.
name: Convento de San Esteban (Padres Dominicos)

excerpt: Historic baroque Catholic church featuring bell towers with sweeping city views.
detail_description: La Clerecía is a historic baroque Catholic church in Salamanca, originally a Jesuit seminary and now home to the Pontifical University. The church features bell towers offering sweeping city views and is still officiated by the Jesuits. Nearby are other notable churches and convents, including the Italian-style church of the Augustinians and the Dominican convent of San Esteban.
name: La Clerecía
address: C. de la Compañía, 5, 37002 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: Founded in 1419 CE, this picturesque covent features a church & cloister added around 1533.
detail_description: Convento de las Dueñas is a 15th-century convent in Salamanca's old town, founded in 1419 for Dominican nuns. It showcases Mudejar architecture and features a church and cloister added around 1533. The building boasts beautiful tiling characteristic of Moorish decor and an ornate Plateresque facade. Visitors can explore the church, cloisters, refectory, and monks' cells while enjoying the peaceful gardens.
name: Convento de las Dueñas
address: Pl. del Concilio de Trento, s/n, 37001 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: Salamanca, in northwestern Spain, is the capital of Salamanca province, part of the Castile and León region. With a history dating back to the Celtic era, it’s known for its ornate sandstone architecture and for the Universidad de Salamanca. Founded in the 1100s and a key intellectual center in the 15th-16th centuries, the university continues to add to the city’s vibrancy with its international student population.
detail_description: Salamanca, located in northwestern Spain, is the capital of Salamanca province and part of the Castile and León region. The city has a rich history dating back to the Celtic era and is renowned for its intricate sandstone architecture. The Universidad de Salamanca, founded in the 1100s, played a significant role as an intellectual center in the 15th-16th centuries and continues to contribute to the city's liveliness with its international student community.
name: Salamanca

excerpt: Grand Gothic & baroque edifice with ornate carvings, including an astronaut added in the 1990s.
detail_description: Salamanca Cathedral is a grand Gothic and baroque edifice adorned with intricate carvings, including an unexpected astronaut added in the 1990s. The Old Cathedral and the New Cathedral stand side by side, making it initially challenging to distinguish between them. Visiting both cathedrals may be more appealing for religious purposes, while those seeking picturesque views and artwork can enjoy stunning interior vistas from the Ieronimus tower.
name: Salamanca Cathedral

excerpt: Small, romantic garden featuring diverse plant species & views of Salamanca cathedral & the river.
detail_description: Huerto de Calixto y Melibea is a charming garden located near the cathedrals in Salamanca, offering diverse plant species and stunning views of the cathedral and the river. This botanical paradise, named after characters from 'La Celestina,' invites visitors to relax in its serene atmosphere while admiring statues dedicated to Fernando de Rojas' literary masterpiece. The garden's historical significance is further enhanced by its proximity to the remains of the Roman Walls.
name: Huerto de Calixto y Melibea

excerpt: Historic Dominican monastery with scenic cloisters & a dramatic facade showcasing ornate reliefs.
detail_description: In the heart of Salamanca, you'll find the Convent of San Esteban, a historic Dominican monastery renowned for its picturesque cloisters and an impressive facade adorned with intricate reliefs. As you explore the area, don't miss the opportunity to visit Plaza de Carvajal and discover the intriguing Cave of Salamanca, steeped in legend and mystery.
name: Convent of San Esteban
address: Pl. del Concilio de Trento, s/n, 37001 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: Elaborately decorated palace, built in 1538, featuring a courtyard with a loggia.
detail_description: Palacio de la Salina is a historic palace in Salamanca, built in 1538 and known for its lavishly decorated Plateresque facade and courtyard with a loggia. It was once the headquarters of the salt tobacconist and later became the Provincial Council's headquarters, hosting temporary exhibitions. The palace stands out from others in Salamanca and has inspired legends due to its unique characteristics.
name: Palacio de la Salina

excerpt: The older of 2 joined cathedrals, this medieval Romanesque/Gothic church features ornate tableaux.
detail_description: In the heart of Salamanca stands the Catedral Vieja de Santa María de la Sede, an impressive medieval Romanesque/Gothic church built in the 12th century. This historic cathedral is renowned for its ornate tableaux, meticulously crafted embellishments, and sculptures adorning its facade. The octagonal dome and the Ramos gate with biblical tableaus are captivating architectural marvels that showcase a rich spiritual legacy.
name: Catedral Vieja de Santa María de la Sede de Salamanca
address: Plaza Juan XXIII, s / n, 37008 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: Iconic, venerable cathedral with revered architecture, historic adornments & scenic tower views.
detail_description: The Ieronimus Tower, also known as the Old Cathedral, is a must-visit in Salamanca. It offers a unique opportunity to explore the medieval towers and enjoy panoramic views of the city. Visitors can walk around exterior terraces, lookout points, and balustrades while admiring historic adornments such as gargoyles and pinnacles. The tower provides insights into architectural evolution from Romanesque to Gothic styles and allows access to hidden parts of the cathedral.
name: Ieronimus Tower (Old Cathedral)
address: Plaza Juan XXIII, s/n, 37003 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: Opened in 2002, this automobile museum features over 100 vehicles & numerous related artifacts.
detail_description: Established in 2002, the Museum of Automotive History showcases a collection of over 100 vehicles and various related artifacts. The museum offers exhibitions that delve into the history of early motorized vehicles, the development of self-powered vehicles, and advancements in auto manufacturing, design, and technology. Visitors can explore rotating displays covering diverse topics such as road safety and cultural niches like Salamanca's motorcycles.
name: Museum of Automotive History
address: Pl. del Mercado Viejo, S/N, 37008 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: This historic 1500s building is known as a grand example of Spanish Renaissance architecture.
detail_description: The Palacio de Monterrey, a historic 16th-century building, is a prime example of Spanish Renaissance architecture. It has influenced various architectural styles and served as an inspiration for other notable buildings. Located near Plaza Mayor, it's part of a charming area in Salamanca that includes the Convent of Las Ursulas and the College of Archbishop Fonseca. The palace features beautiful Renaissance design with a no-photo policy inside until you reach the roof tower.
name: Monterrey's palace

detail_description: Torre del Clavero, a national monument in Salamanca, is a Gothic-style tower that dates back to the 15th century. It forms part of Sotomayor's palace and boasts a unique design with a square base that transforms into an octagon as it rises. The tower features smaller towers at each angle adorned with coats of arms and blind arches. While not open to the public, visitors can admire its beauty from the surrounding streets.
name: Torre del Clavero

detail_description: Iglesia de San Martin de Tours, a 12th-century church situated in the heart of Salamanca's old town, showcases remarkable Romanesque architecture and stunning frescoes. Constructed by the Knights Templar, it stands as one of the city's oldest structures. This iconic example of Spanish Romanesque architecture features three naves culminating in circular apses.
name: Iglesia de San Martín de Tours

excerpt: Sprawling park with shady walking paths, a duck pond with fountains & a playground for kids.
detail_description: Jesuitas Park, located in Salamanca, offers a serene and spacious environment for visitors to enjoy. The park features lush gardens, a picturesque lake with fountains, and playgrounds for children. It is an ideal place to take leisurely walks along the shady paths or relax on the numerous benches scattered throughout the area. Throughout the summer, visitors can also partake in various events such as concerts and theatrical performances.
name: Jesuitas Park
address: Av. de la Aldehuela, 37003 Salamanca, Spain

detail_description: The Museo de Salamanca is housed in the Casa de los Abarca, a former palace with a rich history dating back to the late 15th century. The museum's collection features works from the 14th century to the present day, including Flemish panels, altarpieces, canvases, sculptures, archaeological pieces, metalwork, jewelry and local ethnology. It is particularly strong in Catholic religious art.
name: Museo de Salamanca

detail_description: The Escuelas Mayores de Salamanca, also known as the Upper Schools, is a must-see historical site for tourists exploring the academic streets of Salamanca. The intricate stone carvings on the facade showcase the Plateresque style popular during the late Spanish Renaissance, with filigree-like designs resembling fine silver jewelry. Of particular interest is a tiny frog carving perched on a human skull, which has become an iconic symbol of the university.
name: Escuelas Mayores de Salamanca

detail_description: Cielo de Salamanca, a breathtaking mural attributed to the talented Fernando Gallego, is a true gem nestled within the Escuelas Menores of the University of Salamanca. Created in the late 15th century, this magnificent fresco showcases an enchanting celestial scene adorned with angels and saints, reflecting the medieval intrigue with both astronomy and theology. As one of Gothic art's finest examples, Cielo de Salamanca offers visitors a glimpse into history that is simply unmissable during your exploration of this beautiful town.
name: Cielo de Salamanca

detail_description: Patio de Escuelas Menores is a stunning plaza located in Salamanca, home to one of the oldest universities in the world. The highlight of this pretty square is the magnificent Facade of Salamanca University, considered a masterpiece of Plateresque ornamentation. The patio offers an elegant and uniform arches that create gorgeous backdrops for photographs. It's also known for its connection to several monuments and places to visit nearby.
name: Patio de Escuelas Menores

detail_description: Plaza de Anaya is a charming square in Salamanca, surrounded by beautiful buildings and gardens. It's a great spot to relax and take in the stunning architecture, including the New Cathedral and Anaya College. The area has a bustling atmosphere with tourists, students, and passers-by creating a special vibe. Nearby attractions include Monterrey Palace, the Convent of Las Ursulas, and the College of Archbishop Fonseca.
name: Pl. de Anaya

detail_description: Puente Romano offers a wonderfully romantic view of the river, perfect for both daytime and nighttime enjoyment. The transition from sunset to twilight is particularly stunning, as the cathedral takes on a golden hue in the sunlight. It's an ideal spot for couples seeking a magical and picturesque experience.
name: Puente Romano

detail_description: Tormes is a picturesque area located on the right bank of the River Tormes, offering stunning views of the Roman bridge, Civil War National Historic Archive, Cathedral, and Casa Lis Art Nouveau and Art Deco Museum. The river provides various opportunities to connect with nature through its numerous paths and bathing areas with sandy beaches. Visitors can enjoy the beautiful natural environment and even take a dip in some well-maintained spots suitable for both adults and children.
name: Tormes

excerpt: A lively central hangout at the heart of Salamanca’s Downtown, Plaza Mayor is a pedestrianized square lined with 18th-century baroque facades like City Hall, with its ornate clock tower. Colonnaded arcades house hip cafes and traditional tapas bars with al fresco seating, plus upmarket jewelry stores. Open-air concerts, screenings of major sporting events, and cultural festivals draw locals and visitors.
detail_description: Plaza Mayor is a bustling square located in the heart of Salamanca's Downtown. It features 18th-century baroque facades, including the ornate City Hall with its clock tower. The square is pedestrianized and surrounded by colonnaded arcades hosting trendy cafes, traditional tapas bars, and upscale jewelry stores. Plaza Mayor is a popular venue for open-air concerts, sports event screenings, and cultural festivals that attract both locals and tourists.
name: Plaza Mayor

excerpt: Pedestrians can cross this centuries-old, stone bridge offering picturesque, river vistas.
detail_description: Constructed in the 1st century AD, the Puente Mayor del Tormes is a centuries-old stone bridge providing picturesque river views. The high arch cross the river and is made of 15 granite arches. The bridge was built to connect the inner city with the outside, divided by the Tormes River.
name: Puente Romano de Salamanca

detail_description: Frog Salamanca is a popular tourist attraction known for its richly carved facade, featuring intricate designs and a tiny frog sculpture. The frog holds symbolic significance, representing the fleeting nature of joy in life. Visitors are challenged to locate the hidden frog on the building's front facade, adding an element of fun to the experience. This charming spot offers an opportunity to admire the beautiful architecture and discover the special detail that makes it unique.
name: Frog of Salamanca

excerpt: Built in the 15th century, this university building has a tranquil courtyard & notable mural art.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Salamanca's historic district, the Escuelas Menores de la Universidad de Salamanca is a stunning example of 15th-century architecture. This serene building features a captivating Renaissance courtyard adorned with impressive arcades and intricate mural art. A highlight for visitors is its facade, which boasts numerous figures, including the elusive frog on a skull—a symbol believed to bring academic success to those who spot it.
name: Escuelas Menores de la Universidad de Salamanca
address: Pl. Fray Luis de León, 3, 37008 Salamanca, Spain

detail_description: The Catholic church of San Marcos is a round building with many frescoes from the high Middle Ages. It was discovered in the late 20th century that the paintings had been covered over during the Black Death, and have since been restored.
name: Iglesia de San Marcos
address: Pl. San Marcos, S/N, 37002 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: Remains of a former crypt where, according to legend, the devil would teach black magic classes.
detail_description: Cueva de Salamanca is a former crypt with a fascinating legend that claims the devil once taught black magic classes here. The cultural calendar highlights events like Easter, Water Monday, the Castile-and-Leon Arts Festival in June, San Juan de Sahagun Festival on 12th June, September Fairs and Festivals, and the Mariquelo climb up the cathedral Tower on 31st October.
name: Cueva de Salamanca

detail_description: La Malhablada is a unique spot in Salamanca where visitors can enjoy short 15-minute mini theater performances on the first and second floors. The venue also features a lovely terrace where guests can savor tapas while taking in the view. The intimate setting allows for an engaging experience, with small audiences and talented actors delivering entertaining monologues. It's a great place to unwind and be entertained, offering a cool space with friendly staff and delicious, original food.
name: La Malhablada

detail_description: Iglesia de la Purísima is a 17th-century church located in Salamanca, marking the beginning of a delightful stroll along Calle Compania. The church boasts a Baroque style with a Latin cross plan and two side chapels. Visitors can admire numerous paintings adorning its walls, including works by Jose de Ribera. The church also houses the famous portrait of the Inmaculada by Ribera.
name: Iglesia de la Purísima

detail_description: Salamanca Central Market is a vibrant and historic outdoor market located in the Salamanca precinct on the Hobart waterfront. Every Saturday, visitors can immerse themselves in the lively atmosphere, colorful sights, and diverse flavors from 8:30am to 3:00pm. The market offers an array of fresh regional produce, including meats, cheeses, fish, fruit, breads, and pastries inside a charming 19th-century building.
name: Salamanca Central Market

excerpt: Museum & research center displaying Unamuno's furnishings & other objects, plus 6,000 books.
detail_description: The Unamuno House Museum, located next to the University of Salamanca, was once the residence of University Vice-chancellor Miguel de Unamuno. This 18th-century house has been preserved with his furnishings and personal belongings, offering a glimpse into the life of this influential figure. The museum also houses over 6,000 books and serves as a research center.
name: Unamuno House Museum

detail_description: The Catholic Church is a religious institution founded by Jesus Christ in the first century CE. It teaches that there is one way to find salvation and that this path involves faith in God and obedience to His commandments. The church teaches that humans are created in the image of God and are therefore called to live consecrated lives devoted to serving others. Ultimately, the church hopes that everyone will be saved and come into eternal life.
name: St Thomas of Canterbury Church
Iglesia de San Juan de Sahagún
address: Pl. San Juan de Sahagún, 3, 37002 Salamanca, Spain

detail_description: With time to spare, take a leisurely walk in San Benito Square (Plaza de San Benito). Don't forget to sample the traditional tapa bars and relish standing at the counter while enjoying delicious tapas and sipping on lager beer. Visitors will undoubtedly appreciate Salamanca's unassuming bar scene and lively nightlife.
name: Iglesia de San Benito
address: Pl. de San Benito, 37002 Salamanca, Spain

detail_description: Torre del Marqués de Villena is a historic castle located in the province of Ciudad Real, Spain. The castle dates back to the 15th century and has been restored to its former glory, offering visitors a glimpse into the region's rich history. The architecture of Torre del Marqués de Villena is a stunning example of medieval design, with its imposing stone walls and turrets.
name: Torre del Marqués de Villena

detail_description: Learn about the 1812 Salamanca battle by researching online or reading 'Sharpe's Sword'. Information boards at the top of Greater Arapile and base of Lesser Arapile provide valuable insights. The Monumento Batalla de Los Arapiles y a los Caídos en la Guerra de la Independencia is a significant historical landmark worth visiting to experience its rich history.
name: Monumento Batalla de Los Arapiles y a los Caídos en la Guerra de la Independencia

detail_description: The small catholic church of San Julián y Santa Basilisa is a hidden gem in the heart of the city, and no less beautiful for it. Though not as well-known as some of the larger churches in town, it's still a fascinating place to visit, with its atmospheric interior and stunning decoration.
name: Iglesia de San Julián y Santa Basilisa

excerpt: Vibrant museum with ever-changing contemporary art exhibits, workshops & events, plus a restaurant.
detail_description: Domus Artium 2002, also known as DA2, is a vibrant museum in Salamanca that showcases ever-changing contemporary art exhibits, workshops, and events. Located in a former prison building that was renovated and expanded for its new purpose, the museum offers a unique setting for exploring modern and contemporary art.
name: Domus Artium 2002
address: Av. de la Aldehuela, 37, 37003 Salamanca, Spain

detail_description: The "Monumento a Alberto Churriguera y al Conde Francos" is a captivating bronze statue located in the charming Plaza del Poeta Iglesias, adjacent to the iconic Plaza Mayor of Salamanca. This monument pays homage to two remarkable architects, Alberto Churriguera and José del Castillo y Larrazabal, known as Count Francos, who were instrumental in the creation of this stunning square.
name: Monumento a Alberto Churriguera y al Conde Francos
address: Pl. del Poeta Iglesias, 37001 Salamanca, Spain

detail_description: Capilla de la Vera Cruz is a baroque church in Salamanca, Spain and serves as the headquarters of the five-hundred-year-old Brotherhood of the Vera Cruz. The chapel houses numerous works of art and is considered a true museum. It features a Renaissance facade and its interior is adorned with magnificent sculptures and details on its walls and vault.
name: Capilla de la Vera Cruz
address: Campo de San Francisco, 7, 37002 Salamanca, Spain

excerpt: This museum houses exhibits on the history & culture of bullfighting, including costumes & art.
detail_description: The Salamanca museum houses exhibits on the history and culture of bullfighting, including costumes and art. It was closed for renovations at the time of research, but it is expected to reopen later this year. The museum is full of fascinating bullfighting memorabilia, and it is well explained by Pablo. If you're interested in learning more about bullfighting, this is a must-visit destination.
name: Museo Taurino de Salamanca

detail_description: The Monument to Maestro Salinas, situated at the confluence of Rua Mayor, Vieja y Compañia streets, is a notable sculpture in the historic city center. This magnificent artwork stands near prominent landmarks such as the Clerecía and Casa de las Conchas, on the route leading to the cathedral. The square where it is located witnessed significant historical events during the civil war, including its use as a bunker.
name: Monumento al Maestro Salinas

detail_description: The Christopher Columbus Monument, located in Salamanca, Spain, stands beside the Palacio Anaya and is adjacent to the San Esteban Convent. This statue showcases Christopher Columbus pointing towards the yet-to-be-discovered New World while depicting the faces of King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella who sponsored his expedition. Notably, experts from Salamanca University were consulted and affirmed that Indigenous people possessed full human rights.
name: Christopher Columbus Monument

detail_description: The sculpture Monument to Remigio González "the Poet Adares" is a work of art created by Agustin Casillas (1921-2019) as a tribute to the poet Remigio Gonzalez Martin (1923-2001). This artwork was erected in Corrillo square, where the poet used to sell his books. It stands as a commemoration and recognition of his literary contributions.
name: Monumento a Remigio González "el Poeta Adares"
